Entry.1: Was quite surprised to learn that today I was given orders as la/c. Again I saw my OC Section & explained I did not see my way clear to accept but met with no satisfaction. So will probably have to retain the thing.
Entry.2:
In the afternoon felt off colour and by night time was running a temp of 103 & felt like it. Pains in the shins made their appearance later & Swin sent for the Major who gave me some mixture.

Hard and restless night but in morn the temp had 

fallen to 100
Entry.3: Orders to remain in bed & felt about the same.
Entry.6:
12th} Still in Hosp & improving fast. A.D. Jones, the champ tennis player of Sydney Club was a patient in next bed & we chatted very enthusiastically about sport in general.

Cabled for 20 pounds from Jim to Commonwealth Bank as expecting leave next month.
Entry.7: Wrote several letters this morning & after dinner was discharged from Hospital.
Entry.9: 16th Thursday 17th} Carrying on general duties rivetting Sanitation etc. Every effort is now being made to rivet hutments billets hospitals etc in anticipation of a vigorous enemy air offensive next Summer & we are pushing on with the work here. The Bailleul aerodrome down the road have completed a most elaborate rivetting scheme.
Entry.11: Saw the Anzac Coves tonight at Bailleul. Good show.
Entry.13:
22nd} Weather very mild of late being quite warm during the day.

Tonight we gave Col Maguire a send off from He is leaving to take up position of ADMS of our Division. The new Col - A.F. Jolly made his appearance towards the close of the show & made a good first impression.
Entry.14: Johnny Lee pushed off for Blighty prior to returning to Aussie to complete his course in medicine.
Entry.16: Very clear nights Our planes over each night - several trips
Entry.17:
Went to Bailleul with intention of seeing Pierrots but too late.

Pipe incident with D. Gates Snowy Woodham & Walker.
Entry.18:
In afternoon I tripped along to Steenverk & having found Monckton Camp discovered Dick Lamary (Ist Army Troop Co Aust Engs) & visited Harold Bastian at Watts Lines

Eventually I had a long walk back 

to Ravelsburg and lobbed OK.
Entry.20: moved off from Ravelsburg (C section) & arrived at Westhoff Farm to take over from 6th Fld Amb. At Ravelsburg we handed over to Ist Fld Amb Corp. Macauley - late of our Section - was with the 1st having recently join them.
Entry.21: Balance of the unit marched in today & the 6th moved out to entrain for the back areas.
Entry.23:
Very cold this morn. Heavy Frost.

Elected A. Secy Sports & Amusements Committee yesterday during absence of Jack Virtue. On leave.
Entry.24: At night saw Pierrot Show at Bailleul.
Entry.25:
10th Batt band playing in our Hospital grounds.

Fritz bombing all night though none lobbed near us.
Entry.27: Card tourney 500 won by Eric Lawless Bob Cox second.
Entry.30: Concert by our concert party Capt Bridge Harold Williams Ned Figtree gave a farce. Altogether the show was a success.
Entry.33: Making all kinds of preparations for sports programme football boxing etc.
Entry.34: Euchre tournament at night Pte Hayden (17th Batt) 1 Pte Smith L C (2)
Entry.38: Moonlight at night. Gothas bombing everywhere behind the lines until near midnight
Entry.40:
Preparing for Blighty leave tomorrow morning and the boys preparing to go into the lines again at Underhill Farm (Red Lodge) etc.

Tue
Entry.41:
BLIGHTY LEAVE

Up at 6.30 am & by 9 had everything OK & packed up ready for car.

Was very fortunate in obtaining a complete new outfit - some borrowed.

Blighty leave.

Travelled by Ambulance to Bailleul Station & at 11.15 entrained. Passing thru St Omer

arrived at Calais at about 2pm & was marched to a Rest Camp (no 6 East) some 4 miles away.

As no boat left for Blighty this afternoon we had to do the caged lion act for the rest of day.

Eventually we were packed 16 in a bell tent & spent a miserable night.
Entry.42:
Up early expecting to get a boat soon but after several false alarms we were still there at midday - and spent an hour or two at a Picture Show.

Saw heaps of Fritz prisoners making bomb proof dugouts & occasionally we could hear the coast batteries firing out to sea.

However at 3pm we were paraded again & after going thru all kinds of preliminaries we marched to the wharf and were soon under way.

We left Calais at 5pm & altho it was choppy we made a good trip & put into Dover about 6.30.

Whilst picking our way thru the mines a huge Very light was fired towards us lighting up the water on our rear probably looking for craft following us in.

Got a good seat in train & was soon on way to London - lobbing there about 10pm. Were met at Victoria Stn by an NCO & escorted to Horseferry Rd where we were paid & received new clothes etc. However it was midnight before we were free & one day of our leave had been wasted.

We pushed round to Aldwych YMCA but feeling very tired & after a nibble soon got to sleep.
Entry.43:
Awoke 8am then breakfast & to Goodmans Dentistry where I got some teeth fixed up. I did also some other business necessary.

At night went to Coliseum & saw a Vaudeville program notwithstanding a Gotha raid was expected. Obtained a cubicle at Aldwych & slept well.
Entry.44:
Again to Goodmans as one of the teeth came away. Commonwealth Bank etc & Ymca International office.

At 8 .4

In afternoon met Ralph Davison - who is going to Australia - & with Arthur Martin went to Camberwell to see young Harold bonat.

At 8.45 caught train at Euston for Holyhead passing Crewe & Rugby. I arrived there at about 2 o’clock am.
Entry.45:
Arrived Kingston at about 6am & entrain for Dublin arriving at about 7 and immediately made for Soldiers Club where I had a couple of hours sleep.

Having a letter of introduction to Mrs O’Driscoll of Rathmines I arose at 11 am & had shave etc. & proceeded to the place "Hiltonville" Arden Rd Rathmines & was soon made at home by Mrs O’Driscoll & her two daughters.

Had developed slight attack bronchitis & was feeling off colour & at night the good lady produced some rubbing mixture of euchylyptus eucalyptus.
Entry.46:
In morning felt little better & went for trip on tram to Kingstown & back Very nice seaside resort & pier & harbour.

Home late.

Visited Barracks with Sgt O’Connor.
Entry.47:
Run down town in morning & booked seats for Royal Theatre this evening, Pantomime ‘Aladdin’.

Had photo taken on return journey.

Trip to Phoenix Park in afternoon. Wellington monument. Vice Regal Arch etc.

Theatre Royal at night Aladdin.
Entry.48:
Saw Art Gallery in morning also did some writing

Afternoon to town - barbers.

Feeling no good in stomach - diarrhoea etc no better after tea.

This did not prevent us from going to theatre The Empire - Irish players but unfortunately did not see much of it & was unwell all through the performance.

Got worse later & the good lady of house again prescribed again. Slept well.
Entry.49:
Awoke feeing weak but decidedly better. Spent nearly all the morning in bed & dressing hurriedly was in time to to have dinner & catch 3 pm train

at Amiens St Station for Belfast (by the express) where I arrived just before 6 pm feeling improved.

Got a jaunty car to Eastern railway station & was in time to get the 6.30 for Larne.

On arrival there I saw it was going to be a rough trip as it was then blowing a gale. The boat had not sailed for some days owing to U-boats but I was lucky & she was making brief trip tonight. Some Scotties discharged from Army that day were making merry & when on board they ran a kind of impromptu concert - with aid of a N.Z. friend of mine & others.

The trip was exceptionally rough but we made the journey in good time (2 hours) and on arrival at Stanrar was surprised to see so much cargo on the wharf there awaiting transhipment.

Soon in the train & in due course arrived at Dumfries where I had to change. My train north was not due until 6 - it was then 3 am - So we looked around for a YMCA or some such place for a sleep but in vain - the place seeming very dead and we could not even get a drink until nearly 6. Eventually arrived at Glasgow and it was then snowing (9am). Found a YMCA & did some writing.
Entry.50:
met Eric Cunningham & Joe Astbury soon

after.	

Visited Mrs Maxwell at 7 Doncaster St - near City Rd at noon. (Billy Maxwell’s mother) & had dinner there. Spent afternoon in fixing up billets for night & got a rather good bed at Grand Hotel (Welcome Club) at Charing Cross handy to centre of town. Had tea at YMCA (Lyric) & had a run around after tea.

Saw Joe & Eric off by 9.45 train from Central Station.

Slept well.
Entry.51:
called on Tommy Cunningham at Gardners bld in Jamaica St & later we had dinner together at Langs. Quite a businessmans dinner - excellent place. Kind of help yourself to whatever you like & they trust to your honesty to pay for everything.

Thence to Tommy’s friends office & arranged a theatre party for tonight.

At 7pm a party of us visited Scottish Wholesale Co-operative Society’s Factory at Shieldhall & the inspection was truly interesting some of the things being wonderful. In all we visited 7 different factories in which the following 

articles were being manufactured. Paper bags (90 a minute) all folded, pasted & printed hosiery (made by Singer machines) Jam & treacle tins Cigarettes (500 a minute) & tobacco cakes etc Boots and shoes. Jam. Coat tunics. Trousers. Cabinet making & other things. Hurried back to town and had tea with Tommy’s friend at Daniel Brown. At 7.30 met Tommy & his girl & adjourned to Picture House Sanchiehal St for refreshment & smoke oh.

Thence to Empire Theatre where we could only obtain a box which we did. 

Spent a very enjoyable night - the short being very pleasing. "Hotch Potch" was on. Fred Kitchen leading comedian.
Entry.52:
Paid Tommy a visit at 11.30 am & after a shave we dined together at Grand Railway Hotel.

He then showed me thro the Hotel which is a most beautiful place inside - almost a palace - 400 bedrooms. Saw later the Municipal Buildings, St Georges Sq & the G.P.O. & he left for Edinburgh.

I got a ham & proceeded to Parkhead (Celtic Oval) & saw a Girls

Football match. (Munition girls) England v Scotland. Former won 4 goals nil.

Back to town & obtained a seat in Circle at Kings Theatre. "The Southern Maid" rather a good show. Packed. Was surprised to meet Harold Bas inside.
Entry.53:
met Bas at 10 & intended to see the ship building yards but couldn’t get in at either Browns or Beardmore. So proceeded to Dalmuir West & on to Balloch where we had dinner Then to Loch Lomond thro the Park & it was a splendid view. Very cold & snowing 35 degrees thermom.

Back to town again & had tea at an Italian Cafe.
Entry.54:
Left Glasgow by 9am train & arrived Leeds at 3pm.

During the trip I witnessed some very excellent scenery in the mountains as it had been snowing & the tops were covered in snow. I had some time to wait in Leeds before the Dewsbury train was due so contented myself with a run around town eventually having tea at Grand Hotel in Boar Lane.

Caught 4.10 train to Dewsbury & was extremely surprised at the size of the place My intentions were to find dad’s relations John & Wm Newsome. Fred & Wm Harker & Mrs Ann Harker so sighting a newspaper office I made enquiries but in vain. Passing G.P.O. I found in Leeds Rd a Joe Newsome (grocer) & we had a good chat but apparently not same family. I accepted their kind invitation to stay to tea & had an excellent repast.

At night journeyed to Bayswater & met Bill Cunningham’s Sister Kate & we dined together Back to Aldwych.

Supper & bed.

might add that Mr Green came to see me in Dewsbury this morn & he has promised to make enquiries.)
Entry.55:
Spent morning on writing.

Afternoon met a heap of our boys just arrived from France & thence to Palladium & saw a variety show. Little Tich & others.

Received photo & despatched to various places.

At night with Drake & friends to Daly’s Theatre

Back to France

 & saw a real good show. Maid of the Mountains Supper at Aldwych & bed - with instructions to be called at 5.15am
Entry.56:
Called at early hour. Toilet etc & proceeded to Victoria Stn for train Met Joe Joe Bell on station also Archie Martin returning. He gave me address of his aunt where he had left my diaries: Mrs A.H. Sharman 

38 Watery Lane Wibl Wimbledon SW London

Thence to Dover & after refreshments had to wait several hours 

for boat.

Eventually on board & crossed without incident & ended up at Rest Camp No 6 east.

Slept well.
Entry.57:
Moved off at 12.30 pm & marched to Station entrained & pushed off at 3pm. Arrived St Omer at 5 pm & billeted in Vet Barracks for night Allowed leave in the town until 9pm & with Archie Martin we went for a wander. After a good tea put in at a Picture Show - no good - thence to Pierrot Show - worse

Went to bed with order to awake at 3 am.
Entry.58: Up at 4am & had a cold couple of hours waiting for our train to push off Subsequently we moved at 8 am & the train simply crawled to Devres - our destination. There we were lucky enough to meet one of our ambulance cars & got a lift - 8 Kilos - to our unit where we are soon at home again.
Entry.59: In afternoon a small party of us hoofed it to Devres to have a look over then town & spend rather a pleasant afternoon Cpl Macauly who had recently rejoined us was one of party. Harry Tupper was with us again also
Entry.60:
Commenced work in earnest & did a morning route march

Afternoon - pay & NCO parade.

We are at present in the village of Brunembert northeast of Devres.
Entry.61:
Another route march in morning.

In the afternoon I was instructed to carry on with the sanitation of camp.
Entry.62:
Last few days have been exceptionally warm.

Football training at night.
Entry.63:
Raining & cooler

Bridge game at night.
Entry.66:
St Patricks Day.

At 10 am Snowy Woodham Dick Gates & self left Camp & proceeded on leave for day to Boulogne where we arrived at 2pm.

Dinner at American Restaurant & thence to Esplanade where a France band was playing. Hopped a rattler & lobbed at Wimereaux at almost 3.30.

Called at No 2 Aust Genl Hospl & saw a few of our old boys, inc Geo Jackson Cec Matthews & Glennie. Inspected a couple of wards.

Back to Boulogne & had very nice at same joint.

Thence walk up to the Rue de St Paul and had a glance at the houses of ill fame there. and the Sights one sees there makes one disgusted with the business & we thanked God that these places do not exist in our native land. Back to Brunembert soon after -
Entry.67:
Early in

morning rumor had it that we were to move off at 2pm for an unknown destination & soon this proved correct & all was bustle & excitement.

In spite of fact that above seemed quite o.k. we discovered during the morning that same was only a practice move & not quite as much interest was taken as time wore on. However at 2pm we pushed off with full gear up & as the afternoon was hot we soon raised a good lather.

Halfway to Desvres the whole were "about turned" & we tumbled to the stunt & felt pleased that the thing was only a stunt.We eventually bivouacked the night on a small piece of ground about 1 kilo from Brunembert & spent a fairly good time.

Up at 6.30 & returned to Billets.
Entry.68: Raining all day. Did some letter writing
Entry.69:
Rained all cleared away.

Bath Parade in morning

BEGINNING OF GERMAN OFFENSIVE

 & good one too.

Afternoon Football practice.
Entry.70: At night after a very strenuous football training we were given a concert by 35th Batt Concert Party in the Recreation Room & very good.
Entry.71:
Got quite a shock at 3am where we were all disturbed by the unpleasant news that Fritz had launched his long looked for offensive we were to move up into the lines that day.

We therefore arose at 5 am very solid preparation in clearing up followed. After a short rest during the morning we moved off from Brunembert at 8pm & after waiting all night at Bottinghaus eventually entrained at am next morning feeling very done up.
Entry.72:
We learnt today that the enemy offensive had so far not been successful & that we would probably not have much to do

at present.

Arrived at Caestre where we detrained still feeling weak & tired & then followed a long tedious march with our full kit (minus blankets) to well - goodness knows where.

Marching all the afternoon passing through Godeswachsweld & Becke we reached Watou at nightfall & put up in the town for night with the prospects of another heavy day tomorrow.

Planes bombing thro night but slept well.
Entry.73:
Moved out of Watou at 9.30am had quite a march before we were picked up by motor lorries & was soon being whisked along another stage of journey. Passing Abeele we continued on thro Hazebruck & there saw some very large shell holes close to our roadway & the railway line.

We eventually left the lorries & after a short march arrived at that

 

days destination & billets in Wallon Capelle.

The billets were very comfortable & we were soon comfortable.

In the night we could hear the enemys naval gun shelling again.
Entry.74:
Arose 8am and during the morning received some very unpleasant news from Colonel who informed us that the enemy had broken thro to Bapaume & we would be in action very shortly He also gave us final instructions re medical matters. 

At night we had an excellent feed of eggs & peas & felt set.
Entry.75:
Up again at 8am, & spent the morning in making preparations for another move - making our pack lighter as light as possible. In afternoon we pushed off about 4.30pm & entrained at Morbecque Steenbenque eventually leaving at 9pm.

Travelled in train all night.
Entry.76:
Arrived at Doullnes early this

morning & saw the effects of a bomb dropped near the station.

Marched some two or three kilos out of town - where saw traffic going all directions - guns & men transport etc.

Heard all sorts of contradictory rumours from the front.

Camped in paddock until 5pm when the infantry were moved up in buses to the line. We however had to walk about 15 kilos & set out about 5.15pm. Passing thro several villages Teramsnil being one. (where we saw some Yanks) we continued up to Pushevilliers arriving about 9pm & had to bivouac in the paddock the night.

The Naval Division were coming out at the time.

Quite a number of us were lucky enough to put up in a barn for the night & slept fairly well.
Entry.77:
moved out to Pushvilliers at about 1 pm & marched some 10 kilos thro hilly country to Betancourt & had to pitch a camp there as it was then raining. We hadn’t been there very long before several shells came whizzing across

 & burst closely.

Later in the night some shrapnel shells burst over us doing no damage & this continued throughout the night.

We think we are now about 3 miles from front trenches.
Entry.78:
Someone informed us that it was Good Friday today but none of us could recognise it as such. Weather improved a little this morning.

Orders to move came at 1pm and in half an hour we are on the way.

after 11/2 hrs march we arrived at Franvilliers where we were to all stand by until called on.

From Franvilliers we had a good view of the battlefield & could trace the front line for about 10 miles circle half circle in front of us.

It was a good sight to see our shells & guns going their hardest & occasionally the enemy’s shells could be seen bursting not far from us. Word came sooner than expected and we had no sooner begun a game of cards when 20 

bearers from our own section were urgently needed to support our Brigade about 12 miles south of us. In 15 minutes we were all ready to move & soon the party in charge of Capt Maclean was being carried by lorry to the scene of action. We were told that it was a risky adventure as it was quite possible that Fritz had overlapped our roadway before we passed the danger zone.

It was a long journey & after about 2 hours we passed thro a very nice town called Corby on the Somme.

We beat Fritz by taking another road & eventually arrived at Cashay which we were from which village we were told Fritz was only 200 yds. Things however seemed fairly quiet except for occasionally shells & our guns also had a hand.

Our brigade was handy & as nothing could apparently be done then we were sent back 3 kilos to village of Gentelles. 

We soon made ourselves at home & it was pitiful to visit some of the homes that the inmates had left in a hurry - sometimes leaving their meals on the table.

Throughout the night things got very lively & shells burst all round us. Lay down at 3 am.
Entry.79:
Did not sleep much as the noise of scrap was too much & at daylight planes of both sides were very busy. 

The enemy’s artillery seemed to be very much reinforced too. 

HANGARD WOOD BATTLE

Shells continued to rain in one end of village during morning but none fell near us. After dinner word came for about three squads of our C section to proceed forward to our advanced posts & our squad was included in the party.

(Squad consisted of Dick Gates, Snowy Woodham McCure & self.)

We pushed off to the A.D.S. in rain in company with a couple of squads from A Section. Left some men at ADS Cachay and we then pushed further forward.

 

Our squad were to take up position in the former post & en route we left bearers at the different relay posts.

The road at first was good but later it opened out into a quagmire & even ordinary walking was a difficulty.

During the journey we passed several batteries of medium sized guns & all along the flat cavalry was in position apparently ready for favourable opportunity to push home an attack which was impending.

It was very misty.

After about an hours walk we arrived at R.A.P. which is in the corner of Hangaard Wood. On the Just across the flat in front of us we could see the village of Hangaard - in possession of enemy, and on our own left was a very large town called Villiers Bretoneaux - constantly under shell fire.

Our reception at R.A.P. was rather a lively one as heavy shells were bursting with an awful clap on our right, making our position

precarious.

No sooner had we arrived than patients came en galore for us & a couple of hours extremely heavy work was the result. It was the heaviest bearing I had done to date and every step we sunk into mud half way up to our knees.

The relays were insufficiently manned & our two carries had to be made practically the whole distance - some 3 miles.

As it was getting dark we sent word down to Capt Maclean to send the horse wagon up a little as we could have not have continued otherwise.

Perc Kelly of our boys (now a lieut) was one of our first patients - shot thro lung.

Things got so hot that on three occasions we had to shift position of the Aid Post and the wood on our right got a particularly torrid time.

I mentioned Aid Post but it was simply a piece of ground marked out for purpose &

absolutely no shelter of any kind within cooee.

At about 3 in afternoon the 33rd Batt made an attack but did not do much good except perhaps to inflict casualties on the enemy.

Rain commenced again after dark & we were all wet to skin & covered in mud.

The ambulance wagons however received the pressure and our bearing was continued under more favourable conditions.

The cavalry retired later after losing some horses.

Feeling just about done up we continued on until near morning but also the 34 Batt made another attack this time with success & sent the enemy back a little taking several prisoners.

At 7 am our battalion was relieved and it was about as much as we could do to drag ourselves back to Cachy where we got some bread & jam - it tasted like a feast. 

The wagons took us on to Gentelles where we 

got the mud off & dried our clothes a bit & later had an hours sleep. B section bearers in the meantime going up with another of our battalions.
Entry.80:
Had a good an hours sleep & awoke to hear the enemy shelling the village heavily & some shells went very close to us.

Did not do much work.
Entry.81:
Had a decent sleep & souvenired some food & the boys made a decent meal.

Village again shelled heavily & artillery on both sides exceptionally active.

Only stray squads required for Aid Post work & we continued our rest.
Entry.82:
Enemy again shelled our village of Gentelles - rather heavily & five of our boys were wounded. John Perry (arms & scalp) H.G. McLean (leg) - rather severely. Mackay Jim Siggers & Chas Wynn - not quite so bad.

Things got qui so 

lively during the day that we had to evacuate the village and so were ordered to Boues where our Dressing main Dressing Station was. Even on the road we were not safe & a long range fell uncommonly near our party.

Slept well.
Entry.83:
Spent the day cleaning up & bathing in the river. Had a view round the district from chill just outside the town & at night saw a heavy barrage on a 

VILLIERS BRETONNEUX 

neighbouring wood.
Entry.84:
Awoke at 6 am to hear shells pouring into the village - this continued until about 9.30 am & considerable damage was done. Consequently we were ordered to other end of village to new billets. Soon after dinner I was ordered to proceed up the line again & on arrival at A.D.S. was greeted with a hail of whizz bangs & this was kept up for some time getting some Tommys on the roadway.

At 5pm a party were 

despatched forward to an R.A.P. (34 Batt) & was going our hardest. Earlier in the afternoon a shell had lobbed on the RAP site & killed a bearer & wounded another.

Carrying was very heavy & we as it was raining again we were soon wet through. Fritz attacked heavily that night & 36 Batt made their famous bayonet charge later. Things quietened during the night & towards morning our battalion was moved round to the right to Villiers Brettoneaux & we followed at 6am.
Entry.85:
Had to dodge thro a strafe to get to the RAP in the town & we soon saw that Villiers Brettoneaux was not a healthy place to be in.

We were forced to make our digs in a cellar & after an hour or two we felt a little drier. At 10 o’clock the town was strafed very heavily & at least 4 shells hit an Aid Post covering us with brick dust & bricks 

We however got our patients down to the wagon safely & at 3 o’clock we began to realise that no rations had arrived. So a couple of us looked round for some tucker. Found some potatoes rice etc & cooked some for boys & had a good meal.

After dark the 2nd Aust Div began to arrive & we jumped with joy at the idea of being relieved.

I however feel in for a job to remain behind with the mo. in the woods.

At midnight we pushed out of Villiers Brettoneaux & had a very heavy march to a wood from three Kilos away.

Slept about 11/2 hrs & awoke feeling done up.
Entry.86:
Another march & we took up position in a gully from which position I was despatched to find the ambulance & establish communication.

Although very tired & washed out I had to walk 6 or 7 kilos before I found the ambulance & was greeted with the good news of a relief.

Spent afternoon resting. Slept well.

Our unit hospital is on Amiens Rd nth of Boues.
Entry.87:
All the French papers are going into ecstasies over the defence of Villiers Brettoneux & it is the general opinion of the Tommies that they ran enabling the Germans to make their great advance.

Fritzs planes paid us a few visits & dropped a bomb or two without damage.

Naval guns are tearing it in todays and we seem to have quite a lot here.

A barrage just after dark was a picture. About midnight the planes were over again bombing (Mac and I volunteered to souvenir some potatoes at Gentelles.
Entry.89:
At 10 am our squad left for A.D.S. - went Amiens Rd & arrived without incident.

Immediately after we were established Fritz shelled the roads pretty severely and caught horses, etc. Throughout the day our position was shelled & at night-time Gas was sent over of which we got a taste - feeling rather sickly after it. As there was a spur on our right we got the rest & towards morn rain came.
Entry.90: Towards morning we were ordered to take up another position about 100 yds down the road as Tommy infantry had moved in on our position. We subsequently worked all day hard - Capt Davies included - in re-establishing themselves. Otherwise position was quiet.
Entry.91:
At 10 am a party came to relieve our squad & we returned to our HQ on Amiens Rd nth of Boues.

During the afternoon enemy planes dropped bombs closely & also at night just before more bombs were dropped.
Entry.92:
A French plane came down in field nearby after being over enemy country. At midday an enemy photographic plane was brought down from great height by some American planes. Paid a visit to the plane in the field (French) and saw a naval gun firing.

Revisited our tents today.

Enemy planes have been very fair to our portion of the country & not one bomb has so far been dropped near us.

Bombing again.
Entry.95: Weather very dull. Usual shelling of back areas etc. & usual work.
Entry.96:
Raining

Wednesday 17th Was very surprised to see Bill Howard & Norm Bieler back at unit again after being absent since the Ypres battle of Oct last year. Accompanying them also

 

was ex Staff/Sgt major Johnson who was in charge of A.M.C. Field Hospital at Liverpool in 1915 early 1916.

Large batch of gassed patients came thro tonight said to be by our own gas used by the enemy. News of war not very encouraging just at present. Bailleul & Steenwerck our old homes said the in flames. Merville captured by enemy.

Our boys to date who have been casualties are:- 

Killed. Jack Cox who died of wounds received in Villiers Brettonneux & is buried in cemetery off Albert-Amiens Rd.

Wounded & evacuated

 /4/16 In Genteles

H.G. McLean. Loss of a leg (died of wounds)

John Perry Several wounds

Chas Wynn Chest wound.

MacRay Thigh

Entry.98:
Raining usual duties

At night it became fine again & all night we were subjected to bombing all round us - though none fell in our camp.

It is said that the enemy are using our gas against us & the last two nights about 400 cases have come through gassed.

Friday 19th Bombing again tonight. Beautiful moonlight night

Saturday 20th Very cold in morning & a little snow fell about midnight noon. Our brigade was relieved today by 8th Div Tommies & the brigade is to proceed north to rejoin Div. The 33rd Batt which suffered most during the stunts came out with 94 strong & 1 officer (All HQ gassed in M.O

At 3pm we moved off for our new destination marching through Glisy & Daours we came to Pont Noyelles after 3 hours march & a little later came to Quierreau our destination. There we saw the 11th Fld Amb for 1st time for a month. They had not had such a severe time as we had.

Visited the
Entry.99: Fld amb at night & later slept well.
Entry.100: Beautiful morning. Sunlight goodoh resting. Bombs at night
Entry.101:
Ordinary fatigue during day.

At night visited YMCA in the village - just installed & heard an interesting story of Major Finigans experiences with Light Horse in Egypt & Palestine.

A Fritz plane flew very low over the village just before dark.
Entry.102:
Was Orderly Corp. Beautiful day. Wrote a few letters & in afternoon had a bon bath in the village.

At night planes bombing very heavily.

Awoke at 4am.

Military medals were won by Dick Gates Dug Haig (M.T.) L/c Stan Monk.

Capts Watson & Mailer of the Details were also successful - the former with an M.C. & the latter with bar to MC.

During day - riveting work. The night being clear the Gothas were over towards morning & dropped a good number of bombs in & around Amiens nearby.

We could also hear shells lobbing in the town.

A couple of good yarns are told against some of the boys in connection with the recent stunts. One against Shearman who always had a habit of strutting about with a RFC cap on. 

A Fritz plane which was brought down at Glisy attracted Shearman & when the RFC chaps arrived to salve the thing they began handing Shearman several important parts of engine. In this way Shearman earned some good souvenirs. Another is told against myself. On During our stay at Villiers Brettoneux I souvenired a for Froggie cap. Today a French plane came in on a Tommy field & visitors began to inspect it. One night when I was over with my Froggie cap & no tunic a Tommy major & his SM came across & addressed me

Parley vous Anglais monsieur. I answered Non messieurs & pointing to the French mechanic I said ‘the Pilot. He eventually asked the Frenchie if I was the French Officer & the French said Non les Australie ‘ave kamerads chapeau. I needless

to say kept dark especially when the major said I needn’t have said told him I couldn’t speak English if I was an Aussie.

Another yarn of Jock Smith in Villiers He & a couple of others went to the mayors house during the shelling & discovered a sliding lift for tucker, etc. Sending the lift down he sang out Eggs & chips two please & made to walk away. But lo an answer came up the lift Hullo coming up: & later said it was the best we can do at present. The lift appeared with a bottle of wine and some cheese in it. Some Aussie lags had been billeted in the cellar.

Thursday 30th Early this morning quitted our camp for the Dressing Stn on the Somme bank near between Glisy & Camon & was surprised at the number of men

Entry.157:
After little sleep we packed up our gear & set off for next sector - getting drenched by storm en route.

Passed Veare & Hamelet & arrived at Hayes Post later & first met a party of Americans of 129 Field Amb (U.S.A.) who were to accompany us into our new positions for instruction.

After arrangements had been made I was allotted two Yanks (‘Ten’ & ‘Han’) & proceeded to our post - Two-way Relay - on arrival found it a bit of a funk hole - probably in full view of Fritz on a decent day. The country here for miles was extremely open & our post commander a view for miles of surrounding country. 

We decided to make the best of it & settled down to conditions. At night we realised that Fritz was still at war & he put some stuff round our point.
Entry.158:
However slept well - first decent one for some days. During the day we had to keep our eye skinned for shelling which came spasmodically.

Visited the R.A.P. (Bois de Veare) and they are in good possie - Strafe again at night.
Entry.159:

in. Yesterday I discovered /o settled one of our cars here. Got back after a fairly exciting trip with my Yank (Henny). Raining & mucky all day Henny & I cooking. At night Fritz strafed thru them about all over the shop - not forgetting us & towards midnight the sky cleared & a bon moon came through. Later Gothas came & bombed hell out of everywhere round us.
Entry.160: Had some narrow escapes dodging whizz bangs etc.
Entry.161:

Then the bad news came that Ben Knight (carrying to our Relay from RAP was struck in thigh by a piece of shell & died soon afterwards.
Entry.162: Again Fritz went mad & had us awake nearly all night adjusting our gas respirators etc.
Entry.163:
Tonight was the capper of all. It was clear night & Gothas 

 

again did the necessary. We did not sleep a wink as he saturated the place with gas & had us coughing & spluttering like hell

nearing daybreak he put on barrage on south side of us & raided but we didn’t get much to do except dodge some plane & barrage stuff.

Its funny listening to some of the Yank tales etc. whilst playing our daily game of cards.

Roller skates on top of motor ambulance turning corners etc Fritzs boy on the gun - pulling string hard.

Entry.170:
Proceeded with three other squads to 35 Batt at midday Rested throughout the day & at night we moved up to the front line - about 6 miles. This of course took us a couple of hours as we accompanied our Batt - the 35th - and both the infantry & us were well laden. We had stretchers & blankets to juggle in addition to our own stuff. As a route we took ‘B’ back. Passing through Aubigny Fouilloy & Hamelet we left Hayes Post behind & a little later got among some shells but no damage

BEGINNING OF OUR HUGE OFFENSIVE

was done. Leaving Hamel on our left we crossed some very open spaces Subjected to machine gun fire & eventually arrived at the hopping off position where we took up our positions until the barrage. It was very unsatisfactory being a sunken road & communic. trench and therefore liable to draw fire.

We however rested here a couple of hours without incident.
Entry.171:
One of the most exciting & adventurous days of my life.

Towards 4 am a heavy mist came up shrouding everything. At 4.5 am aeroplanes came over. We knew they were ours altho we couldn’t see them. Sounds of tank engines was thickly drowned by the planes.

At about 5 minutes to zero - (4.20) I left a trench I was occupying to put my gear in a place where I could find it afterwards on the sunken road and had no sooner done so when heigh Presto & gee the heavens opened up in flame & we knew at once our barrage had begun. We couldn’t see very much & wondered if the Tanks had succeeded in getting in possy. Afterwards we knew

they had though a couple got lost in the fog. To make things worse our smoke bombs made it impossible to see more than 10 yds anywhere. Five minutes later Fritzs barrage came down on us like a ton of bricks & our cover was scanty. We were covered in mud several times & one piece of shell caught me in knee doing no damage Nearby Freddy Lee got a piece in the arm & was out of action. Fifty or so shells must have burst within 40 yds of us without doing much damage & about an hour after the barrage I became anxious to know if our boys had got thro. Then the wounded began to arrive & the prisoners in scores. We souvenired some prisoners to carry for us but not before we had made one trip to RAP & got lost for 5 minutes in fog. Eventually we found the RAP - near Veare wood.

Soon we heard the good news - that our objective was gained & although we had plenty of wounded to look we noticed the 4th Divvy going thro us to carry on the advance. The enemy guns were gradually becoming silent too.

After fixing up the wounded

here we moved up behind our battalion - passing over Fritzs front line noticed some dead Germans & other things also droves of prisoners still coming back.

Went thro the enemy outfit & discovered one who was only wounded & sent him back with some other Fritzs. Reached an RAO & got some stuff.

Later we pushed right forward to our Batt some 4000 yds in front of old front line. Several Tanks were there too.

We could plainly see the heavy shelling for village of Cerisy on our left & also Warfusse - captured by us on our right.

There we dug in & slept well.
Entry.172:
Awoke at 8am after breakfast went across to 33 Batt for our ration They were near Warfusse. Whilst there we were shelled with a rubber gun but escaped OK.

It is very noticeable the sanitary conditions here dead Fritzs left unburied for weeks also horses. Examined a battery of guns left in his haste & also ammunition. Found 6 tins of Havelock tobaccies but how he got them we don’t know.

The Batt remained on this possy all day.

 

At 7pm a heavy barrage opened on our left flank & we tipped that we were making a hit across the river. The barrage continued for a couple of hours.

Since yesterday morning we have advanced about 15 kilos here, capturing 18,000 prisoners over 200 guns. Corps H.Q. Railway gun & other things.

Bombing by Gothas at night.
Entry.173:
Rested all day - inspected a couple of planes down nearby - one a Fritz who was downed by an American who also lost his plane by following the Fritz down. He however escaped with slight injury. 

Near dark we moved up again into the front area with 35the Batt marching about 5 kilos passing Morcourt we arrived at our R.A.P. in dark. Soon after arrival the Gothas came across & gave us a deuce of a time bombing everywhere in our vicinity.

The 12th Field Amb were in possession of the dugout we were allotted & as they were not moving out for a couple of hours we slept upstairs. The line of dugouts we were in were old Fritz outfits & in the advance he had quitted in a hurry leaving behind a QM Store

 & canteen beside other stores.

About 1000 yds away he had evacuated a hospital completely equipped & we recaptured about 300 stretchers which we had abandoned (the British I mean) in the March retreat. On the march up to our positions we passed score of big guns captured from the enemy - one set in particular were large ones said to have fired on Amiens - 6 inch naval.

Some 5.9s we had turned round & were firing at him with his own stuff.

At any rate he sustained a number of casualties near the captured Hospital with bombs - including 12 horses.
Entry.174:
We had to carry across to near Peronne - Villers Brt Rd to Hospital with our wounded & today had a tout de suite journey. He was using his naval shrap gun across our track.

Again at night he strafed badly & had us ducking about some. Once more the Gothas came over & simply emptied their bombs in our valley.

Tonight we advanced the line 1000 yds & the 11th Brig surrounded a village - capturing no prisoners. At midnight we were disturbed & informed to prepare to move out any time now & so packed our belongings together

in anticipation.

At 4 am we got a carry across to Hospital & orders came for us to proceed back to a wood nr Warfusse - Lena Wood.

Monday 12th Marched back to Lena Wood examining big guns en route. arrived in time for breakfast.

Prisoners for this stunt increased to 21000 & guns over 200.

Three enemy planes brought down nr our wood.

Rested during morning. Our casualties for this hop over very light.

Our batt the 35th only had about 50 casualties during the actual hop over Casualties heavier on left of flank nr Cerisy.

In the ambulance our casualties were:

Killed Just prior to stunt Ben Knight in Bois de Veare. Buried at Daors.

Wounded
Entry.175:

Monkhouse (ear) & Steve Hartley (both hands) & Ryder.

Tonight the Battalion received orders to move out & at dark we pushed off. And what a journey we had.

Soon after starting the Gothas commenced to come across & very shortly bombs were being dropped all round us. But the climax came when passing thro a gully a cartload just missed us

 & the Battalion went a flat as a pancake. Luckily no one was hit.

We eventually passed thro Hamel & after 3 hrs of it arrived at Veare - looking very different & bivouacked for the night.
Entry.176:
Not much doing today. left resting - bath etc. Towards night orders came to rejoin our units & we pushed up with Staff Carr. Passing through Hamlet Fouilly & Aubigny we reached Daors in time to find a couple of Gothas acting the goat again. From the woollen mills we were taken by ambulance to our M.D.S. at Bussy & after a drink

of cocoa etc rigged up a bed for night under the stars
Entry.177:
In morning proceeded to Daours & had a change of underclothing & swim & felt OK.

At night we saw a Pierrot show (The Cooees) - in Bussy felt it a good respite.
Entry.178: Clean up etc change of program at Pierrots which we saw. Met Ben Melton just returned after being gassed at Villiers Bret

Entry.182:
Moved off from Daors & marched thro Corbie to Smiths Farm where we had tea. Marched thence thro Vaux to Sailly Le Sec

After tea & a swim my squad with two other squads detailed to return to Smiths Farm & arrived there in time to commence duty as night loading party.

Not much doing (Yanks - Tennesson & Hanavan returned from line tonight & we had a chat together.
Entry.183:
Slept nearly all day. At night however a sudden order came to report at once to our unit & we knew that something must be doing.

Beautiful moonlight night. Taken to the unit HQ at Sailly-le-Sec and slept for remainder of night.
Entry.184:
Swim & clean up in morning & at 1.30 pm we (all bearers of B & C Sections) marched out in sweltering heat & dust & made Sailly Laurette our first stop.

Our squad on this occasion were not in the advance party for the line on

first time since stunt began for the Divvy & we moved up to a Reserve Bearer Post to rest until called for.

However we did not rest long although we slept little.
Entry.185:
At dawn our barrage opened & thoughts of At 7.30pm wounded began to arrive & we summed up that our boys were meeting with solid defences & also discovered that the enemy knew of the hop over Consequently the casualties were high.

A hurried breakfast & then - five of our boys came thro wounded & visions of Passendale & other stunts came to mind 

ETINGHEM

We were soon whizzing up to the scene of action & the shelling showed that Fritz had plenty of artillery here.

At 9pm we established a relay on the road between our R.A.P. & Etinghem - rather a bad spot.

An hour later we moved up further - establishing a relay in a sunken road on left of Etinghem & about 200 yds from advance RAP.

There we carried on all day without 5 minutes spell & at dusk Fritz shelled like hell - particularly the village below us. This necessitated our carrying overland along the hill to

ETINGHEM and BRAY

our ADS
Entry.186:
We were still carrying at midday though things had eased off.

During the afternoon we moved up again to RAO and there established ourselves at night dark.

Had not been there very long when 40 Batt told us of a hop over to get Bray- right in front of us & despite the fact we were done up we had to do the carrying.

Sleep was out of the question for the RAP on our left continued to bring us cases until at 1am our barrage burst forth & soon the boys were on the move. 

Then we commenced work again in earnest & carried about 4 cases each before prisoners began to arrive & relieved the strain a bit.
Entry.187:
The boys got Bray all right - surrounded it.

We had nasty experience with some 8 inch stuff but no damage.

Young Rochford of A Sect was killed yesterday on our left.

Was pretty busy until midday & some of us lazed for an hour.

At 3pm we were ordered to have a sleep nearby. At 7pm we were relieved by A Sect bearers after being about 60 hours without 

sleep or rest.

We proceeded to Quarry A.D.S. & was soon asleep bombs in galore causing numerous casualties among Tommy artillery but we missed it.
Entry.188:
Still at Quarry. On awaking my left eye was closed - bitten by an insect - & I had to have the thing bandaged. Still another barrage at 2 am & our boys still going well beyond Bray - did not meet many Fritzs.

This morn Light Horse sent thro. 

In the afternoon we moved up again well beyond Etinghem this time & dug in - in a quarry used as a loading post. A couple of anti’s belted out soon after our arrival & knocked stones etc everywhere.

Our squad were detailed as loading party & near midnight a heavy storm drenched everything.

However we managed some sleep but in morning my right eye was settled by something & my left being not much use I felt uncomfortable.
Entry.189:
As I was almost blind Staff Carr sent me down on a horse to Chipelly MDS for some treatment & I reached there about midday & soon began a treatment which

improved the eyes. The doc said that I had been bitten by insects & would soon be OK again.

Met Bert Forrest towards night.

Ben Taylor, Birch, Stuckey & Flood came through wounded.

Gothas at night - but slept well.
Entry.190: Slight improvement Did nothing but rest. Showery.
Entry.191:
Very much improved. Ken Milton came down line to go on leave. Left our boys in Chateau at Suzanne. All OK.

Weather improved.
Entry.193:
Up at 4.30am & on the move soon after en route to Suzanne to open MDS there. Passed thro Ettinhem & Bray - the latter place not much knocked about but Fritz had cleared out almost everything of value - even furniture. However near Bray goods yard we saw some very large ammunition & engineers dumps which he had to leave in his retreat. Some 8 inch naval shells were pearls. Timber was in abundance.

The country here looked excellent for defense works & it speaks volumes that it was captured with such small losses.

Passing Cappy on our right we passed several ammunition dumps & arrived at Suzanne at about 9am.

But sad to relate I learnt some very bad

news here for during my absence my squad had been knocked about - Snowy Woodham being killed & Dick Gates badly wounded. Also Sullivan, Bill Howard wounded Wagstaffe slightly & Geo Street of 10 Fld Amb killed. Happened near Curlu. I was considered still not fit for bearing & given a clerks work at main Dressing Station Suzanne.

Later receive

Wounded coming thro fairly thick.
Entry.194:
On awakening I was greeted with more bad news - that three of our boys had been killed by a big shell near Clery. Josh Gibson went away from the square to find a decent track & when he returned it was to find that Wilf Boyes & Albert Clarkson had been killed instantly & Rabinovitch so badly that he died later.

Today was one of the busiest I have seen & wounded simply poured in. Our boys had been trying to get Mount St Quentin to dominate Peronne. A goodly number of prisoners also came thro.

hadn’t a spare moment all day. Some very bad wounds. Over 100 wounded Fritzs made things awkward too. However toward night things quietened & we received the news that our boys had got Peronne

Monday 2nd Not quite so busy

Some prisoners went through here & did the goose-step past Divisional HQ. It was caused quite a commotion. The news of our boys being in Peronne was confirmed today, also the storming of Mont St Quentin.
Entry.197:
Visited Suzanne Cemetery & saw Snowy Woodhams & Rabinovitchs graves also Geo Street. Also all buried beside each other. Will Boyes & Clarkson buried at A.D.S. Curlu or Clery.

At night saw Pierrot Show - the Cooees - 1st for some time.

Prisoners to date since July number 128,000. The Australian Press representatives visited the village today.

Inspected tombs of wealthy Marquis D’Estormel today & saw how the Hun had burst open the business probably for loot. Bombs during Pierrot show.
Entry.198:

Good news from north. captured 10000 prisoners.
Entry.199:
Bath & clean up etc.

At night all the bearers moved up to Curlu but I was omitted & ordered to remain until morning.
Entry.200:
After breakfast we pushed off on a long march towards Peronne. Travelling cross country we arrived by bad roads at Curlu - which the Hun had used as a CES, well dug in. There we passed the bearers & as we advanced a little further we had a good view of old 1916 battlefields. Just about here it was where Snowy Woodham was killed.

Some distance further we came to Clery or what remains of it. Just about here Clarkson & Wilf Boyes & Rabinovitch was killed Mont St Quentin hove into sight & passing over a couple of railings we came level to the Mont 

Heading south came to Halles our destination & some pie Oh.

Great fires could be seen burning all along the front the Hun burning villages.

Night duty. The Gothas gothed.
Entry.201: Nothing of interest our boys still going ahead. Line extended to Roisel.

Entry.204:

On Mont St Quentin about a kilo away 4 Pioneers

killed by a trap attached to a dead Fritz.

Strolled around village Despatched several letters to Aussie.

Clear at night.
Entry.205: All our bearers came up here from Curlu today. Raining.
Entry.207:
We got a piano from somewhere & spent quite an enjoyable night in sing song & dancing - very good fun. However the best thing of the day was to follow. At dark the Gothas commenced to come across well laden. The first two were picked up by searchlights & went back to their lines. The next was also picked up and held by lights for some time at the same time the Archies & machine guns put an excellent barrage around him. But from out of the sky we could see something signalling us a morse lamp. We quickly saw what was happening & the barrage ceased. Then into the rays of the lights came a big speck which chased and gained rapidly on the Gotha. Moments passed & when the speck happened to be some yards off it fired & the Gotha exploded in a mighty flame - coloured lights of all description went up all around it. It fell to the ground amid cheers from all the neighborhood. 

The next one appeared & was dealt with similarly except that it did not catch fire & the speck this time was about it. So ended a victorious night for RAF.
Entry.209: Excellent weather again. Good news from South. American & French attacked in front of Metz - 5000 prisoners. At night we saw a bon programme - one of the best - by Sentimental Blokes (1st Divvy) The girl impersonators were perfect (Kemble)

Raining. Awaiting orders to move all day.

Yanks marched into village this afternoon. Rested during afternoon & at midnight prepared to march out.
Entry.223:
Left Halles at 1 am & marched through

HINDENBURG LINE

the early morning. It was cold & suitable for marching & we made good progress.

Passing Mont St Quentin we entered Peronne (with moon shining very strongly) & moved thro the town - looking well in the moonlight - Passing thro Russu & other villages we realised we were nearing Passed thro Longavennes we came to Villiers-Fannon & at dawn arrived at our destination St Emilie.

We hadn’t been there many minutes when the barrage opened like a thunder clap & we knew things were moving.

St Emilie got very lively a little later as the enemy sent over some heavy stuff

BATTLE FOR BONY

Yanks Aussies Tommy labor Coys & armoured cars were in great numbers.

At first things appeared to go well as the balloons moved forward news leaked thro that the Yanks thro want of experience had not got their objective - failing to mop up & our boys had caught it warm. This proved to be correct.

He continued to pepper the Lempire - St Emilie road hot & strong.

Then we got some bad news of our boys. Robert taking up rations on pack horses

had run into a nest of machine guns outside Bony & was killed beside losing 7 horses. the other drivers had narrow escapes. 

In addition the bearers got in among machine guns too & Ken Milton (back) Harrod (back) & Cpl Owen (hand) were wounded.

Macey Hec Reeston Bob Cox were gassed.

We were to have established an ADS in the Hindenburg Line at Bony but the idea was abandoned for the present.

It was bitterly cold & casualties mostly Yanks began to flow thro.

At midnight just as we expected to get a little sleep a call came & 8 of us & myself were toute de suited into a car & sent linewards.
Entry.224:
Passing thro

Lempire we arrived at the ruins outside village & there discovered some 20 cases which we proceeded to load on the cars - shelling going on the while.

Halfway thro the job another call came from further forward and we proceeded to the outskirts of Bony to a shell hole - (I was in charge of party) & we narrowly missed shells on the mucky roadway several times.

On arrival there a sniper kept us on the qui vive but we succeeded in getting the 6 wounded & returned to Lempire - & thence to St Emilie arriving back without further incident at 6am & turned in.

Raining during the day.

Tom Temperby left us to go to no 2 AGH Boulogne on exchange & a jolly good chap thereby leaves us.

Position much same at night.
Entry.225:
Twelve months ago today since I was wounded.

News good from all fronts. Bulgaria said to have thrown in sponge.

Frank Haynes evacuated sick. Buckley & Adams E gassed.

In our sector our Divvy had improved the position wonderfully & Fritz is retiring.

 

 

At 4pm we proceeded forward again to Lempire Roussoy to establish ADS.

Saw Frank Carr & some other diggers nr Guillemont. Night duty. Casualties light at first.

Today got my first glimpse of well-known Hindenburg line but did not get near enough to make a close inspection.
Entry.226:
Not very busy. At dawn a Fritz plane made a detour but did not make an attempt on the balloons & only dropped a couple of bombs.

The line has gone ahead considerably & Bony has been mopped up. Line at Gouy now.

Slept well during day. 

On awakening at tea time we were greeted with good news that Divvy was being relieved & coming outside perceived Tommies marching up (50th Div) from Salonic.

However we had to carry on all night as R.H.M.C. did not arrive to relieve us.
Entry.227:
Our relief arrived early this morning and we accordingly pushed off back to St Emelie without further incident. We heard en route that the hop over by Tommies was great success going about 6 kilos past Hindenburg Line.

Arrived at St Emelie for breakfast and all the morning our bearers were reporting back from the Battalions. 

Staff Sgt Frank Carr &

Andy Chalmers & Pte Bridge left us to proceed to Aussie on leave. Gave them a cheer. Soon after dinner we assembled & commenced a march back. Passing thro Villiers Fannon Bieramont, Aizecourt to St Pierre farm nr Templeux le Fosse. There we made a Camp for night.

A party of us found a billet in an old quarry nearby & we were soon comfortable.

Thursday
Entry.228:
Still at St Pierre Farm. Received the news that Armentieres & have fallen.

Played cards & shooting in the quarry. Slept well.

Friday
Entry.229:
Soon after dinner we struck camp & marched on Peronne Rd towards Peronne. Halting after 1/2 hrs march we were entrained on light railway & was soon whizzing on our way - arrived at Mont St Quentin - & from there marched thro Peronne to railway Station. Sheltered in some old houses until near midnight - when we entrained in the usual cattle trucks.

Travelled throughout the night - Slept at intervals very cold & arrived at Airanes about 8 am. Saturday
Entry.230:
Saw Bert Forrest there & he gave us some biscuits - very acceptable.

Marched about 11 kilos thro Wiry & Forceville to Neuville au bois - our

destination & very excellent. Pretty fresh looking billets & clean too.

To our surprise we were billeted in the Chateau an imposing building - very clean. - probably the best billets we have had yet. People were very hospitable not having seen Aussies before.

At night visited Oisemont a very nice village a couple of kilos away. The railway runs thro the village & we had for first time a decent feed.

Slept well.
